results.title: A Jig: The River Cree
results.creator_credit: Thames and Clyde Film Company and Stanley Russell
results.brief_description: Introduction to a traditional Scottish dance the jig, set to the music of “The River Cree. Demonstrates the steps and movements of the four couples in a complete jig.

results.title: A is for atom
results.creator_credit: John Sutherland Productions and General Electric
results.brief_description: Explains by animation the nature of a single atom and its nucleus, the way in which atoms differ from one another, and the significance of the terms radioactive and stable. Describes the experiments which led to nuclear fission, the separation of mass uranium for the first atomic bomb, and the mass production of the artificial element plutonium. Explains the functioning of an atomic pile and the peace-time uses of atomic energy in agriculture, industry, transportation and medicine.

results.title: A is for architecture [edited version]
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Robert Verrall and Gerald Budner
results.brief_description: An edited version of “A is for Architecture”. A panorama of ancient cities, palaces and temples whose splendour awed the eyes of all mankind - recreated in colour by the skill of the animation artist. In documenting the changing concepts in architecture through the ages, the film moves from one tradition to another, illustrating how each reflects the sentiments and values of the time, from the massive temples of the Pharaohs to the soaring skyscrapers of today.

results.title: A is for architecture
results.brief_description: A panorama of ancient cities, palaces and temples whose splendours awed the eyes of all mankind - recreated in colour by the skill of the animation artist. In documenting the changing concepts in architecture through the ages, the film moves from one tradition to another, illustrating how each reflects the sentiments and values of the time, from the massive temples of the Pharaohs to the soaring skyscrapers of today. Winner of eight film awards, including Rapallo Film Festival, Italy and Canadian Film Awards.

results.title: A is for AIDS
results.creator_credit: Peregrine Productions, Charlotte K. Beyers and Aron Ranen
results.brief_description: Made for children at primary-school level, this program features Dr. Andy Answer, an animated dog, who explains to three young children some of the facts about AIDS. Using computer animation, interviews with young children who are HIV Positive, and clear and simple illustrations the video explains how the HIV virus is transmitted and how the immune system works. The video dispels many of the myths about the disease and features excerpts from the Magic Johnson press conference where the basketballer revealed his positive status and argued against discrimination and prejudice.

results.title: A Hungarian fairy tale = Hol volt, Hol nem volt [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Hungarofilm, Objective Productions, Lajos Ovari and Gyula Gazdag
results.brief_description: This strange, beautifully realised, almost wordless film combines gritty social realism and symbolic poeticism to tell the story of a boy’s fruitless search for his father. The film begins with a highly romantic scene in which a beautiful young woman and a handsome stranger meet at a performance of ‘The Magic Flute,’—an encounter that results in a passionate one-night-stand and the birth of a child. Though the father is never heard of again, Hungarian law states that every child must, by the age of three, have a father’s name entered on their birth certificate. The woman, with the encouragement of the bureaucrat who completes the form for her, invents a fictional name, address and occupation for the father. Years later, after his mother’s untimely death, the boy, now in his teens, sets out to find his mythic father. Beginning as a satire about Hungarian bureaucracy, the film introduces surreal and comic elements as the boy’s journey progresses. Eventually it evolves into a provocative allegorical fantasy about Hungarian identity and politics. Features a particularly strong performance by David Vermes as the teenage boy and impressive black and white photography. Cast also includes Maria Varga, Frantisek Husak and Eszter Csakanyi.

results.title: A Hundred years underground
results.creator_credit: BBC-TV, British Transport Films, Edgar H. Anstey, John Shearman and Jon Rowdon
results.brief_description: The story of London’s underground railway, from the building of the original Metropolitan line with its steam drawn trains, to its latest addition, the ultra modern Victorian line. Lord Morrison tells how London Transport became the model for similar undertakings throughout the world; artist Henry Moore shows how the tube became a wartime refuge, and tunnel engineers explain the problems, past, present and future, of building and operating this vast system.
